item.title: China Is Said to Be Holding Jia Jia, a Journalist, Over Xi Jinping Letter
item.description: The letter, which Mr. Jia’s friends said he denied writing, was an incendiary denunciation of the Chinese president that implied threats to his safety.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: Under President Xi Jinping, the Chinese government has taken an increasingly hard line toward dissent, imprisoning dozens of activists, lawyers and journalists.

item.title: Opinion: I Love the U.N., but It Is Failing
item.description: I joined to protect the helpless from rape and murder. I never dreamed our own forces would be the rapists and murderers.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY BANBURY

item.title: Sinosphere: On Social Media in China, Size 0 Doesn’t Make the Cut
item.description: Women and a few men in China are boasting about their thinness by posting photographs of their waists hidden behind a piece of A4 paper.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A 24-year-old Chinese student who did not want her full name to be used holding up a piece of paper to show the slimness of her waist.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Obama's Flawed Realism
item.description: The president has sold American power short. Trump's American irredentism feeds off this.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Chinese Tycoon Criticizes Leader, and Wins Surprising Support
item.description: The unexpected defense of an outspoken real estate tycoon has exposed uneasiness about President Xi Jinping’s calls for unquestioning public obedience.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Ren Zhiqiang, an outspoken property developer, at a book club in Wuhan, China, in September. Mr. Ren’s social media accounts, which had tens of millions of followers, were erased after he posted remarks critical of President Xi Jinping.

item.title: Sinosphere: With ‘Smog Jog’ Through Beijing, Zuckerberg Stirs Debate on Air Pollution
item.description: When Mark Zuckerberg, of Facebook, posted a photo of his run Friday, he set off reactions that ranged from mocking to genuine concern about his health.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Sinosphere: China Resumes Diplomatic Relations With Gambia, Shutting Out Taiwan
item.description: The move raised the prospect of a renewed contest between China and Taiwan over allies, as Gambia had maintained ties to Taiwan for nearly 20 years.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The foreign minister of Gambia, Neneh MacDouall Gaye, with the vice president of China, Li Yuanchao, in Beijing this week.

item.title: Sinosphere: Giant Maoist Slogans Form Core of Chinese Director’s New Film
item.description: The slogans, visible only from the air, were constructed in 1968, two years after the onset of the decade-long Cultural Revolution.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Cleared earth and gravel form the Maoist slogan “Serve the people,” one of five navigational markings built near a military aviation school in eastern Xinjiang in 1968.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Spy Who Sold Secrets to C.I.A. Gets 8 Years
item.description: The 32-year-old, identified as Markus R., was arrested in 2014, and the revelation cooled relations between Germany and the United States.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Azerbaijan: Critics of Government Freed in Amnesty
item.description: Azerbaijan’s government pardoned 148 prisoners, including journalists, human rights activists and political opponents on Thursday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Musharraf Leaves for Treatment in Dubai
item.description: The former military ruler Pervez Musharraf left Pakistan on Friday for medical treatment after the government lifted a travel ban imposed on him as he awaited a trial on treason and other charges.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Leaked Memo Reveals Plan to Stop Leaks
item.description: Kazakh officials will have to leave their smartphones at the door of government buildings beginning in line with a new policy aimed at preventing leaks of confidential documents.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: North Korea Fires Missile Into Sea, South Korea Says
item.description: The projectile, which appeared to be a medium-range ballistic missile, crashed into the waters off North Korea’s east coast.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Morocco Orders U.N. to Cut Staff in Disputed Western Sahara Territory
item.description: Reacting to comments from the U.N. leader, Morocco demanded the evacuation of 84 members of the organization’s mission in Western Sahara, where it has played a peacemaking role for 25 years.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Officials Warned That Congolese Soldiers Were Linked to Rape
item.description: Just months after troops from the Democratic Republic of Congo arrived on a peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic, allegations of sexual abuse began piling up.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: European Union Grapples With Plan to Return Migrants From Greece to Turkey
item.description: The Continent’s leaders had challenges reaching a consensus on the crisis as humanitarian groups have called the proposed policy a violation of international law.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: The Bulgarian-Turkish border near Lesovo, Bulgaria. Leaders are grappling with a plan to return refugees from Greece to Turkey.

item.title: Obama to Unseal Files on Argentina’s ‘Dirty War’
item.description: President Obama is moving to declassify records that could show what the United States knew about Argentina’s brutal crackdowns of the 1970s and ’80s.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: U.S. Service Members Punished for Strike on Hospital in Afghanistan
item.description: The Defense Department has disciplined at least a dozen military personnel for their roles in an airstrike in October on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed 42 people, senior military officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The damaged Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in October. The airstrike killed 42 people.

item.title: Defense Secretary Calls Iranian Seizure of American Sailors ‘Outrageous’
item.description: On Thursday, Ashton B. Carter told the Senate Armed Services Committee that Iran’s actions in January may have violated international law.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: An image released by Iran showed American sailors in Iranian custody in January. They were released after about 14 hours.

item.title: Tempers Flare in Brazil Over Intercepts of Calls by Ex-President ‘Lula’
item.description: An uproar accompanied the former leader’s swearing-in as President Dilma Rousseff’s chief of staff on Thursday and the release of recordings of him suggesting intimidation of investigators.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s former president, after he was sworn in as the chief of staff for the current president, Dilma Rousseff, in Brasilia on Thursday.
